segments.text: We had actual World War II tactics where defensive lines were established and tanks came.
Much of our operations, I think, was defend your own backyard, defend your supply base,
and patrol out, even with long-range patrols, patrol to find where the enemy is.

And the difficulty in Vietnam, as opposed to most of the wars that have been fought by the U.S. conventional forces, is that we never were able, in many instances, to find him, fix him, and fight him.
nowhere he is where we can fight him in a conventional manner and destroy him.
The Vietnamese had a very good record in, I mean, I'm talking about the NDA and the VC, of ambushing U.S. forces, inflicting serious casualties and disappearance.
They were very good at, by and large, very good at disappearing.
What did you think of the fighting ability of the North Vietnamese Army and the Viet Cong?
The Vietnamese Viet Cong and NVA?
More so the NVA, I believe, than the Viet Cong.
were highly respected by me and the South Vietnamese.
The South Vietnamese respected the NDA soldier as a soldier and treated them with respect when captured.
The Viet Cong was considered a traitor, a criminal, a hoodlum, and had almost no respect.
because they were traders.
But as far as their fighting ability, their fighting ability was no different than that of the United States.
And as someone said, as I recall, in 1964, with his back against the wall, the South Vietnamese soldiers
is an outstanding fighter by the same token.
So was the NBA, so was the Vietcom.
The problem was, in all cases, getting their back against the wall where we could get them to, where we could find them and get them to fight.
As you know, our support, except during tremendously bad weather,
was always much, to our advantage, overpowering.

We had artillery, we had naval gunfire in certain areas, and we had aviation, whether it be helicopters or fixed-wing fast-movers, fighter bombers, the Air Force and Navy and Marine Corps fighter bombers.
We had the support that they could only dream of.
and be the recipients of loads of bombs, napalm rockets, and automatic cannons.
So if we could find the VC or MDA, it was almost for sure an automatic win.
The nights only, and I'm talking about the hours of darkness,
and the hours of overcast, bad weather, and so forth.
Only those periods of time normally belong to the enemy.
And mostly the, except for, as you recalled earlier, the strategic hamlets, except for the strategic hamlets, mostly we outnumbered.
And even our own
internal support, artillery and mortars, machine guns, heavy machine guns, outweighed by many times over the support and the firepower of either the NVA or the Viet Cong.
What do you feel that the military learned from Vietnam
I would say that there were several things, and I would just name a couple.
Number one, it is not desirable to become embroiled in a guerrilla warfare situation on the mainland of Asia, that the conventional forces, regardless of its support
cannot win a war, cannot successfully fight a war without total commitment towards the war.
Regardless of the type of war to be engaged in, that the military cannot succeed without support
from the civil populace of the United States, nor can they win that same war without the support of the civil populace of the country that we're fighting in.
I would say that we learned some favorable things from the war in Vietnam.
We learned the capabilities of aviation assets.
We learned the capabilities of our own troops.
We learned the capabilities of our weapons systems.
And we learned the weaknesses of our weapons systems.
We discovered in many cases that while helicopters are great for moving troops, that they are very vulnerable.
in situations such as we had in Vietnam, that they are vulnerable to small arms fire, they're vulnerable to machine guns, and to surface-to-air missiles.
And while we paid for that knowledge, I believe that technological innovations to defend against those things
are in fact still being utilized and we're still learning from the experiences in Vietnam.
While a great deal of the personal memory of Vietnam is lost to the military now, I believe that there is still a great

institutional memory of Vietnam, that the lessons of Vietnam have been passed from trainer to trainee, and the trainee subsequently becomes a trainer and has not completely lost all the knowledge that was gained, and the actual combat experience
has not all been lost.
How did you try to fight the war?
Primarily from day to day.
I tried to, depending upon what my individual job and mission might be, to try to accomplish what I perceived my mission might be.
planned for the next day with the hope that the next day would be there to let me carry out what I had planned for that day.
It was not a situation that I planned, began in 1964 to plan to carry out what I did in 1971.
It was a situation that in each tour I had
varying missions that required me to do different things from time to time and I relied on my own training to guide me in what needed to be done and a sense of I suppose empathy for my
Vietnamese counterpart if I had one, and empathy for the Vietnamese population, understanding that I don't understand the Vietnamese culture or any other colonial culture.
I have some empathy toward their desire to be left alone, and whatever I can accomplish
leaving them alone to give them some help and assistance towards being what they wanted.
I tried to accomplish that within my capabilities.
Did the seeming apathy among the peasants towards any particular form of government or towards the war in general, did that frustrate you at times?
that they seem not to want us to be there, or did they ever seem not to want us to be there?
They, to my knowledge, I never witnessed an incident where the Vietnamese populace was anti-US or anti-government.
There were certain individuals
that I observed and I saw who were primarily anti-government forces, anti-U.S. forces.
But there were no, that I recall, no overt demonstrations of Yankee go home.
To my knowledge, I don't
I just don't recall ever seeing any signs that said Yankee go home or any of those things.
I think that primarily the only sign that I did see which said Yankee go home was on the back of a U.S. Marine Corps armored personnel carrier.
So even in 1971-72, the relations between the military and the populace was still good?
Do you feel that?
Uh-huh.
I didn't have any close friends in 71-72.
The Vietnamese had been some of the military.
But the Vietnamese, I had
In 71-72, I had Vietnamese people working for me as laborers, secretaries, clerks, cooks, bartenders, that type of thing.
They worked for me, and they were all very friendly.
Of course, that may have been employee-type relationships.
I did not spend any more time
in the civilian community that I absolutely had to because I had plenty to do elsewhere.
In other words, I didn't have that much time that I could get my job done and then get out of the division headquarters area and into town.
I just didn't go.
Didn't spend any time.
During the 68-69 era, we were frequently in our regular combat patrols.

We might wind up in a village and stop and have a beer, cold drink, or a bowl of rice or something of that nature, a bowl of soup maybe, and talk to the local cafe or restaurant proprietor, if you could call them a restaurant today.
It was whatever.
And they seemed to be friendly then.
The merchants, the souvenir merchants around Marble Mountain in 64 were reasonably friendly.
And they were reasonably friendly in 68 and 69.
As a matter of fact,
I'm talking only about what was overt now.
I have no idea.
These same people may have, as soon as we left, gone and sent a message, gone or sent a message to a local BC commander and told them where we were, what we were doing, and what their strength was.
I have no idea about that.
But the very few occasions that I
was in the civilian community in 71 and 72.
It was, they were, it seemed as if maybe we were treated as honored visitors.
Of course, we were spending money.
And that was, I guess that was what they were looking for.
I can't say that I was ever treated as poorly in Vietnam as I've been treated in the United States.
What do you think of journalists?
Did you ever have a journalist go out with you on an operation?
Oh, yes.
I had frequently saw journalists in our area.
is the higher the headquarters, the more journalists we normally had.
And some of the journalists that I knew were pretty doggone good soldiers.
And some of the journalists that I knew were nothing but cremadons.
And on a few occasions, they actually interfered with our combat
But I don't think highly of a journalist.
As you may know, I was reported on at least one occasion in a national magazine to have been wiped out.
And I believe that was the 68-69 era, probably sometime in the late summer of
And I frequently saw things in the news magazines and in Stars and Stripes that I knew were to be false.
But in most cases, their attitude was gathered, I believe, probably from dealing with the
and in my case, not checking their facts before they started writing, basing their news reports on less than accurate information.
How did you feel about, feel knowing that you were leaving, knowing you'd lost the war, or that the army, that the war was lost, or did you, I mean?
I don't believe we really thought the war was lost.
I thought that the program called Vietnamization was working at that time.
probably that most of us, and myself included, thought that our last tour there was meant to install backbone or grow backbone in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, South Harvard.
I think that we believe that we've been successful because
Now, you must realize that this was the Delta, and that we were fighting the main force NVA in the Delta, and we were up fighting them along what in the area is called the Parrot's Beak.
I've never really known exactly why they call it the Parrot's Beak.
except maybe it's the section of the border or maybe one of the rivers.
It looks like Parrot's Peak.
I really don't know.
It's adjacent to Cambodia.
And I think we believed that we were winning the war.
And I think that the incidents that occurred about, I believe it was 1975,
When the North actually invaded in strength and rolled up the army and finally made it into Saigon, wasn't that January of 75?
Yeah, but we'd already pulled out, hadn't we?
Most of our, we had pulled out, before I left there, we had pulled out all of our
to the best of my knowledge, all of our ground combat troops.
And the primary thing that was remaining was a little bit, maybe a few batteries of artillery, and I think they had moved out.
And all we had left was what they call the air cavalry.

and that was primarily helicopter helicopters with a few uh a few squads of infantry attached and it was during most of my 1971-72 tour um it was a vietnamese war at least in the delta there were no u.s combat troops in the delta except for the air cad and
They were winning, and I never thought that we lost the war.
When we're talking about the United States, the United States, contrary to what I may have said earlier, we didn't lose the war.
We were prevented from winning the war.
in effect lost the war by default.
In other words, we quit and moved out.
And you cannot win a war when you quit and move out.
Now, I'll accept the fact that the South won the war up to a point, and then they lost it.
If you want to keep score, they were head on points up to and including January of 1973, and maybe as late as March of 1973.
As I recall, the very last advisor came out of the 7th Division in March of 1973, which was a little over three months after I left there out of the 7th Army.
So, and at that time they were still, if you want to look at body count, they were still winning.
They were killing more NBA and BC, primarily NBA, than they were losing soldiers.
So, I guess maybe they were head on points as late as March of 1973, but apparently,
And you'll have to remember, too, that the amount of supplies being delivered to Vietnam was seriously cut.
The budget, the United States budget for support of the South Vietnamese military was severely cut before the NBA
came across the demilitarized zone in force.
So the division commander had to cut back on the amount of artillery he could use.
The aviation assets available had to cut back on the rockets and machine gun ammunition.
It was just a situation where you
to fight the way you have been taught to fight over a period of years with almost unlimited assets of ammunition and combat support.
Now, when it's no longer there, you don't know how to employ your troops the way you used to.
And you'll have to remember also that this was one of the few times
that the NVA attacked in force and became, I'm talking about the first time that I recall, was the summer offensive of 1972.
Spring and summer offensive in 72, maybe just after tail offensive in 72.
where they came across in force.
And they were beaten to a standstill and pushed back, wiped out.
And this is the second time that they've done it.
The first time they had the assistance of U.S. combat support, combat service support, to deliver ammunition, replace losses, and so forth.
In 1975, that luxury was no longer there.
They ran out of ammunition, they ran out of troops, and there was nothing left to fight with.
So I guess if you can call that a win or a loss, it's whatever you want to call it.
So essentially, although they were on the winning side in 1972-73, when we left, when our support was...
pulled from them that it made the turning point towards the end?
Somewhere between those two dates when the budgets were cut and our logistical prop was removed, then they no longer had the ability to fight as we had taught them to fight.
Thank you.
